pullRequest.body:
Prove that, if we have an adjunction `adj` between functors `F` and `G` equipped with `CommShift` structures by an additive monoid `B`, and if `adj` is compatible with the `CommShift` structure, then:
- The adjunction `adj` is compatible with the pulled back `CommShift` structures on `F` and `G` by any map of additive monoids `φ : A →+ B`.
- The opposite adjunction is compatible with the opposite `CommShift` structures on `F.op` and `G.op`.

- [x] depends on: #20364

---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Deletions:

- ...

will be invisible to reviewers.

using the following format:

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20364~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

There is a useful general statement about natural transformations, and the case of adjunctions follows from it. The structure of the code should be as follows (the definition of the opposite of an adjunction should be fixed...):
```lean
namespace NatTrans

attribute [local instance] Functor.commShiftOp

variable {F} {G : C ⥤ D} [F.CommShift A] [G.CommShift A]

lemma commShift_op (τ : F ⟶ G) [NatTrans.CommShift τ A] :
    NatTrans.CommShift (C := OppositeShift C A) (D := OppositeShift D A) (NatTrans.op τ) A := by
  sorry

end NatTrans

namespace Adjunction

attribute [local instance] Functor.commShiftOp NatTrans.commShift_op

variable {F} {G : D ⥤ C} (adj : F ⊣ G)

-- to be moved to `CategoryTheory.Adjunction.Opposites` as a replacement
-- of the broken `opAdjointOpOfAdjoint` (Note: this definition made
-- sense before #16317 when adjunctions where defined in mathlib with data
-- including the unit, the counit and the `homEquiv`, but now 
-- that the `homEquiv` field has been removed, the following would be
-- much better)
@[simps]
def op : G.op ⊣ F.op where
  unit := NatTrans.op adj.counit
  counit := NatTrans.op adj.unit
  left_triangle_components _ := Quiver.Hom.unop_inj (by simp)
  right_triangle_components _ := Quiver.Hom.unop_inj (by simp)

lemma commShift_op [F.CommShift A] [G.CommShift A]  [adj.CommShift A] :
    Adjunction.CommShift (C := OppositeShift D A) (D := OppositeShift C A)
      adj.op A where
  commShift_unit := by dsimp; infer_instance
  commShift_counit := by dsimp; infer_instance

end Adjunction
```

Okay, two questions:
- First, I tried of course to do something similar with pulled back shifts, but I run into annoying problems. I could fix them by adding an `@[ext]` attribute to `Functor.CommShift` and using it to prove lemmas like `Functor.CommShift.id (PullbackShift C φ) = Functor.commShiftPullback φ (𝟭 C)` (and similarly for compositions), however, I am wondering whether there is a simpler way.
- Second, if I understand well you want me to edit the file `CategoryTheory.Adjunction.Opposites` and change the definitions of `opAdjointOpOfAdjoint` (and, I presume, also `adjointOfOpAdjointOp`). However, do you also want to change the names? There are many options for "opposite adjunctions" with a complicated naming scheme (like `adjointUnopOfAdjointOp`, `opAdjointOfUnopAdjoint` etc), so if you change one name wouldn't you need to change all their names?

For the second question, we have `Equivalence.op`, so that `Adjunction.op` seems a good name to me, and similarly `Adjunction.unop`. I think we can get rid of the variants `adjointUnopOfAdjointOp` and `opAdjointOfUnopAdjoint` which are basically unused (you may introduce deprecated aliases referring to the more relevant new `op` or `unop`). (We probably have these variants because `F.op.unop` was not defeq to `F` in Lean 3, but it is now.) It may be better to do that in a separate PR.

For the first question, I do not have time to look at the details now, but it would be better if we can avoid proving equalities between `Functor.CommShift`s. I am not sure it is relevant, but it may be possible to introduce an isomorphism between two copies of the identity (with different `CommShift`s on it) and show a `NatTrans.CommShift` for it?
The problem seems to be that Lean does not think that the identity of `C` and the identity of `PullbackShift C φ` are the same, so this solution might work, yes.

I was able to make the thing build without proving equalities between `Functor.CommShift`s and without `erw`, but it's not exactly elegant code. In particular, I have to use `@` versions of lemmas all the time because I need to give instance arguments explicitly. I would be grateful for any tricks that can avoid this.

I implicitly suggested the following:
```lean
def PullbackShift.functor : PullbackShift C φ ⥤ PullbackShift D φ := F

variable {F} in
def PullbackShift.natTrans {G : C ⥤ D} (τ : F ⟶ G) :
    PullbackShift.functor φ F ⟶ PullbackShift.functor φ G := τ
```
Then, `Functor.commShiftPullback` (and similarly for `NatTrans`) can be made instances, and the compatibilities with the identity functors and the compositions become:
```lean
variable (C) in
def PullbackShift.natIsoId : 𝟭 (PullbackShift C φ) ≅ PullbackShift.functor φ (𝟭 C) := Iso.refl _

variable {E : Type*} [Category E] [HasShift E B] (G : D ⥤ E) [G.CommShift B] in
def PullbackShift.natIsoComp : PullbackShift.functor φ (F ⋙ G) ≅
    PullbackShift.functor φ F ⋙ PullbackShift.functor φ G := Iso.refl _

instance : NatTrans.CommShift (PullbackShift.natIsoId C φ).hom A where
  comm' a := by
    ext
    simp [PullbackShift.natIsoId, Functor.commShiftPullback_iso_eq]

instance {E : Type*} [Category E] [HasShift E B] {G : D ⥤ E} [G.CommShift B] :
    NatTrans.CommShift (PullbackShift.natIsoComp φ F G).hom A where
  comm' a := by
    sorry
```
This is actually what I'm trying at the moment, except I had no idea you implicitly suggested anything. It's still a mess though, needs more work.

Or more precisely, I had resigned myself to introducing a type synonym for the functor, but not for the natural transformation. I see that the solution was to "boire le calice jusqu'à la lie"... Of course, to be totally consistent there should be a `PullbackShift.adjunction` carrying the new `CommShift` structure defined at the end, but I'm not sure I want to venture there.
Well, I hate to write this, but `PullbackShift.adjunction` makes a lot of sense actually. The proof of `Adjunction.commShiftPullback` is now just `dsimp` + `infer_instance`.

There are some unnecessary parentheses:
```suggestion
  unit := (NatTrans.PullbackShift.natIsoId C φ).hom ≫
    PullbackShift.natTrans φ adj.unit ≫ (NatTrans.PullbackShift.natIsoComp φ F G).hom
  counit := (NatTrans.PullbackShift.natIsoComp φ G F).inv ≫
    PullbackShift.natTrans φ adj.counit ≫ (NatTrans.PullbackShift.natIsoId D φ).inv
```

```suggestion
@[simps (config := .lemmasOnly)]
def PullbackShift.adjunction {F} {G : D ⥤ C} (adj : F ⊣ G) :
```

I believe that the same design which has worked well for the pulled back shift should be also used for the opposite shift. Could you introduce new definitions of `OppositeShift.functor` and `OppositeShift.natTrans`. This will also allow a better definition of the `F.op.CommShift ℤ` instance in https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Triangulated/Opposite/Functor.lean

Let me make sure that I understand. You want `OppositeShift.functor` etc to be the one that carry the `CommShift` instance for the naïve opposite shift, so that we avoid instance clashes later when `F.op` gets a `CommShift` instance for the "triangulated" opposite shift?
Yes.

Okay, I introduced `OppositeShift.functor/natTrans/adjunction` and this does give a shorter definition of `commShiftOpInt`.
(I did not change the doc string at the start of `CategoryTheory.Shift.Opposite`, since I am not sure that the file is stabilized yet.)

pullRequest.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Shift/Opposite and CategoryTheory/Shift/Pullback): `CommShift` structures on adjunctions are compatible with opposites and pullbacks

source.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Triangulated/Adjunction): the left adjoint of a triangulated functor is triangulated
